newsitem.title: USA: INTERVIEW - Boole & Babbage seeks acquisitions.
newsitem.headline: INTERVIEW - Boole & Babbage seeks acquisitions.

text.p: Flush with cash and a rising share price, Boole & Babbage Inc is looking to buy rival software companies, aiming to double its revenue in three years, the company's chief executive said on Wednesday.

With size comes clout, which relatively tiny Boole & Babbage needs to fend off its rivals in the field of system-management software, including the likes of International Business Machines Corp and Computer Associates International Inc.
"We want to be in a position where people have to consider us when they are looking for this type of software," Paul Newton, Boole & Babbage's chief cxecutive said in an interview.
Boole & Babbage, based in San Jose, writes software that helps technicians keep track of the performance of sprawling computer networks such as airline reservation systems or telephone operations.

The system-management software niche -- estimated by brokerage Hambrecht & Quist to generate about $1.5 billion to $2 billion in revenue annually -- has proven lucrative for IBM and Computer Associates. Increasingly, however, smaller players have struggled as customers choose just one or two vendors.
Since Newton took control of Boole & Babbage in October 1991, he has bulked up the company, seeking to build it into one of the big boys.

Revenue has increase 51 percent to $167.2 million in the fiscal year ended September 1996 from $110.5 million in 1992. Total assets have more than doubled to $207.1 million in the same period, while Boole & Babbage's stock in the past 12 months has doubled to 23.
In December, Boole & Babbage used $25 million of that stock to buy rival software supplier MAXM Systems Corp, a closely held company with $20 million in revenue in 1996.
That's just the start, Newton said.

"We would like to do a couple more of these," he said. "We have a decent stock price, we got a reasonable amount of cash, and we have a much more efficient engine for selling and distributing product."

Newton also plans to wean Boole & Babbage from sales of mainframe software and to expand the company's product line to include so-called client-server programs for managing networks made of personal computers and workstations, he said.
With its acquisition plans, half of Boole & Babbage's revenue would come from client-server management tools by 1998, up from about a third currently, Newton said.
Wall Street analysts who track Boole & Babbage said they liked the strategy.
"The acquisitions help," said Joseph Farley, an analyst at UBS Securities in New York. "It's something that will give them more visibility."
Farley also praised Newton for managing Boole & Babbage's growth. "This is one the best-run technology companies."
Still, Boole & Babbage has to contend with IBM and Computer Associates, companies that dwarf Boole & Babbage in revenue and marketing resources.
IBM on Tuesday said that revenue from its Tivoli systems-management unit tripled in the fourth quarter from the year-earlier period.

Computer Associates, the second-largest software company after Microsoft Corp, has spent lavishly and lined up marquee partnerships with computer vendors to promote its CA-Unicenter systems-management product.

Newton said he recognized the competitive threat. To deal with it, Boole & Babbage focuses tightly on selling so-called console management software -- programs that give technicians at a glance an overview of the performance of the network.
While IBM and Computer Associates sell similar products, some customers prefer Boole & Babbage's Command/Post.

"We have been running Command/Post for years," said Russell Guinn, an enterprise-monitoring specialist at Shell Services Co, a computer services company specializing in the energy industry. "It has some keen features that the others don't."
